input_args.examples: {'document_id': ['0000040', '0000040', '0000040', '0000040'], 'document_source': ['NIHSeniorHealth', 'NIHSeniorHealth', 'NIHSeniorHealth', 'NIHSeniorHealth'], 'document_url': ['http://nihseniorhealth.gov/leukemia/toc.html', 'http://nihseniorhealth.gov/leukemia/toc.html', 'http://nihseniorhealth.gov/leukemia/toc.html', 'http://nihseniorhealth.gov/leukemia/toc.html'], 'category': [None, None, None, None], 'umls_cui': ['C0023418', 'C0023418', 'C0023418', 'C0023418'], 'umls_semantic_types': ['T191', 'T191', 'T191', 'T191'], 'umls_semantic_group': ['Disorders', 'Disorders', 'Disorders', 'Disorders'], 'synonyms': [None, None, None, None], 'question_id': ['0000040-13', '0000040-14', '0000040-15', '0000040-18'], 'question_focus': ['Leukemia', 'Leukemia', 'Leukemia', 'Leukemia'], 'question_type': ['susceptibility', 'symptoms', 'exams and tests', 'treatment'], 'question': ['Who is at risk for Leukemia? ?', 'What are the symptoms of Leukemia ?', 'How to diagnose Leukemia ?', 'What are the treatments for Leukemia ?'], 'answer': ['For the most part, no one knows why some people develop leukemia and others do not. Most people who have known risk factors do not get leukemia, while many who get the disease do not have any risk factors. Studies have identified the following risk factors for leukemia. - older age  -  male  - white  - working with certain chemicals  -  smoking  - exposure to very high levels of radiation  - certain health conditions  -  past treatment with chemotherapy or radiation therapy.  older age male white working with certain chemicals smoking exposure to very high levels of radiation certain health conditions past treatment with chemotherapy or radiation therapy.', 'Common symptoms of leukemia may include -  fevers  - frequent infections  - feeling weak or tired  -  headache  - bleeding and bruising easily  - pain in the bones or joints  -  swelling or discomfort in the abdomen (from an enlarged spleen)  -  swollen lymph nodes, especially in the neck or armpit  - weight loss.  fevers frequent infections feeling weak or tired headache bleeding and bruising easily pain in the bones or joints swelling or discomfort in the abdomen (from an enlarged spleen) swollen lymph nodes, especially in the neck or armpit weight loss. Symptoms of acute leukemia may include vomiting, confusion, loss of muscle control, and seizures.', 'There are no standard or over-the-counter tests for leukemia. Your doctor can request lab analyses for leukemia that include blood tests that check the levels and types of blood cells and look for changes in the shape of blood cells. The doctor may also look for signs of leukemia in the bone marrow or the fluid around the brain or the spinal cord', "Treatment depends on a number of factors, including the type of leukemia, the patient's age and general health, where leukemia cells have collected in the body, and whether the leukemia has been treated before. Certain features of the leukemia cells and the patient's symptoms also may determine treatment options."]}
